docs.lead_paragraph: ''It's very sad for me to say tonight that after 100 singles and many albums, this man hasn't received any royalties off his music,'' said Judy Adams, the widow of the New Orleans singer Johnny Adams. Mrs. Adams spoke after her husband was honored at the Rhythm-and-Blues Foundation's 10th Annual Pioneer Awards on Thursday night at Sony Studios here. If the Grammy Awards is a time for the music business to celebrate itself, then the Pioneer Awards, traditionally held the night after the Grammys, is a time for the industry to make reparations. In addition to keeping alive the memory of groundbreaking, chart-topping and often forgotten rhythm-and-blues musicians, the foundation was formed to help musicians and their families get royalties for their hits, erase longstanding debts to record labels and pay for everything from health insurance to funeral expenses. In 10 years, the foundation has given out over $2.5 million to musicians.

headline.main: Accepting Kudos and Cash, A Song in Their Hearts

docs.abstract: Rhythm-and-Blues Foundation holds 10th Annual Pioneer Awards in Los Angeles; foundation was formed to help musicians and their families get royalties for their hits, erase longstanding debts to record labels and pay for everything from health insurance to funeral expenses; foundation has given out over $2.5 million to musicians; widow of one of those honored, late New Orleans singer Johnny Adams, scores record executives she claims exploited her husband with 'shake-hand deal slavery'; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Who are all these 43.4 million Americans, at the Census Bureau's last count, who do not have health insurance? Who runs the least risk in going without it? (Children.) Who runs the most, medical and financial? (Sick people approaching 65.) Who is most likely to have it? (People over 65.) Not to have it? (Adults who work for low wages.) Who doesn't care? (Invincible youth.) For more than a decade, an average of a million Americans a year have either lost their health insurance or failed to obtain insurance for which they became eligible. The reasons vary: prohibitively priced premiums, reduced employer coverage, the welfare overhaul.

headline.main: UNINSURED IN U.S. SPAN MANY GROUPS

docs.abstract: United States, despite its bounty, stands almost alone among industrial nations in not providing free basic health care for all; growth in number of uninsured is startling anomaly in economy that has been able to subdue inflation, unemployment and budget deficits; health care analysts say unless something is done, situation will get worse as rise in cost of insurance and health care outrun wage gains; problem is now engaging interest of politicians across political spectrum; there is debate on how to help uninsured, but not on who needs help most: 49 percent of Americans without health insurance are full-time workers with incomes below poverty line; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty months ago, after more than a decade on public assistance, Ann McGinniss transformed herself from a welfare mother into a working mother. She now follows the rhythms of suburban parenthood, rising before dawn to prepare her daughter and son for school, then driving from her home in Peekskill, N.Y., to her bookkeeping job at a nearby car dealership.

headline.main: Welfare Policies Alter The Face of Food Lines

docs.abstract: Empty Shelves, first of two articles on growing evidence across nation linking huge drop in food stamp rolls and growing lines at food-charity doors; new welfare policies are swelling lines at soup kitchens and food pantries; some people are working poor caught in middle--new welfare regulations deem them too well off for public assistance, but their pay is not enought to put food on their table; some are immigrants, in US legally but cut off from food stamps under new Federal welfare laws; some seeking food handouts are simply unwilling to deal with hassle or stigma of seeking food stamps in today's anti-welfare climate; together, they are changing face of food lines long occupied by addicted, disabled, and generally down-and-out; photos (L)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed as the company worked to turn around its financial situation. The health maintenance organization reported a loss of $18.8 million, or 23 cents for each diluted share, compared with a loss of $284.7 million, or $3.58 a share, in the period a year earlier. Oxford, based here, had been expected to have a loss of 78 cents, according to analysts polled by the First Call Corporation.

headline.main: Loss by Oxford Narrows, but Not Enough

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc eports fourth-quarter loss of $18.8 million compared with loss of $284.7 million in year-earlier period; revenue fell slightly to $1.13 billion from $1.14 billion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Winning the biggest unionization drive in more than half a century, the Service Employees International Union gained the right today to represent 74,000 Los Angeles County home-care workers who feed, bathe and clean for the elderly and disabled. The organizing drive -- more than twice as large as any other in decades -- shows the labor movement's new aggressiveness and its new focus on recruiting low-wage workers, women and minorities.

headline.main: IN BIGGEST DRIVE SINCE 1937, UNION GAINS A VICTORY

docs.abstract: Biggest unionization drive in more than half century is won by Service Employees International Union, which gains right to represent 74,000 Los Angeles County home-care workers who feed, bathe and clean elderly and disabled; organizing drive shows labor movement's new aggressiveness and its new focus on recruiting low-wage workers, women and minorities; Los Angeles County's home-care workers earn state minimum wage, $5.75 an hour; they voted overwhelmingly for union to obtain better wages as well as health insurance and paid vacations, benefits long denied them; union officials will begin bargaining over next few weeks with county authority that supervises home care; organizing drive highlights shift in economy and in labor's focus away from manufacturing and toward service sector, especially toward health care, in which 1 million of 12 million workers are unionized natiowide; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Winning the biggest unionization drive in more than half a century, the Service Employees International Union gained the right today to represent 74,000 Los Angeles County home-care workers who feed, bathe and clean for the elderly and disabled.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: As a bipartisan commission wrestles with restructuring Medicare financing for the next century, it needs to modernize Medicare's benefits. That means adding a prescription drug benefit to the program. Liberal Democrats in Congress and on the commission consider a drug benefit crucial to Medicare reform. But Republicans are worried that expanding coverage to drugs could add upward of $20 billion a year in costs to a program already headed for insolvency. The political reality is that neither camp can achieve what it wants without the other. The commission is considering a plan drafted by Senator John Breaux, the group's chairman, that would replace the existing Medicare system with a market of private and government-run health plans. The hope is that competition will help control growth in Medicare costs over time. But radical restructuring will be a hard sell politically without adding drug coverage. Conversely, it is unlikely that the Federal Government can afford to cover drugs without making substantial changes to traditional Medicare, including injecting more managed care into the system.
docs.abstract: Editorial says bipartisan commission seeking to restructure Medicare financing needs to add prescription drug benefit to program (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory commission studying the future of Medicare agreed today to work past its March 1 deadline so members could try to devise a major new benefit covering prescription drug costs. The drug benefit thus emerged as the linchpin of any broader agreement between Republicans and Democrats on the panel.

headline.main: Medicare Panel Working Toward Drug Benefit

docs.abstract: Federal advisory commission studying future of Medicare agrees to work past its March 1 deadline so members can try to devise major new benefit covering prescription drugs; issue is linchpin in bid by Sen John B Breaux, panel chairman, to win needed votes for his proposal to offer each Medicare beneficiary fixed amount of money to enroll in private health plan or regular Medicare program; Medicare official Richard S Foster tells panel that its proposed program changes would increase premiums for most beneficiaries, even as they slow program growth and save Government money (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that a Federal judicial panel on multidistrict litigation had rejected a motion by the Justice Department to combine all Medicare fraud lawsuits against the company. Analysts had said that Columbia would be likely to pay about $1 billion to settle the charges that it overbilled Medicare, and the company had given a $1 billion letter of credit to the Justice Department. But the ruling could delay a settlement. Columbia also said that its profit from operations had risen to $27 million, or 4 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1998, rather than the 23 cents a share that analysts had expected, and that it would repurchase up to $1 billion of its stock. Standard & Poor's lowered its credit rating on Columbia yesterday to what it called speculative grade.

headline.main: PANEL REJECTS MOVE TO COMBINE COLUMBIA/HCA LAWSUITS

docs.abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says Federal judicial panel on multidistrict litigation has rejected motion by Justice Department to combine all Medicare fraud lawsuits against company; ruling could delay settlement; Columbia also says its profit from operations rose to $27 million in fourth quarter of 1998; adds it will repurchase up to $1 billion of its stock; Standard & Poor's lowers its credit rating on Columbia to what it calls speculative grade (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The sale of a financially troubled health maintenance organization's policies for 27,000 Medicare patients could be completed by Friday, officials said yesterday after a state judge approved the sale. On Monday, Judge Anthony J. Parrillo of Superior Court approved an application by state regulators to sell the policies of the American Preferred Provider Plan of Newark to Horizon Health Care Plan of New Jersey, said Emerald Kuepper, a deputy state attorney general.

headline.main: Judge Approves Sale Of H.M.O. Policies
